hints_html:
Review the statement of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.

The statement says that

\(\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx}\int_{a}^{x}f(t)\,dt = f(x)\).

How does this differ from your problem? Can you fix it?
hints_latex: Review the statement of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.

The statement says that

$\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx}\int_{a}^{x}f(t)\,dt = f(x)$.

How does this differ from your problem? Can you fix it?
hints_raw:
Review the statement of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
The statement says that 

<math> \displaystyle \frac{d}{dx}\int_{a}^{x}f(t)\,dt = f(x)</math>.

How does this differ from your problem? Can you fix it?
question: 8 (a)
sols_html:
We have via the fundamental theorem of calculus that

\(\displaystyle I_{a} = \frac{d}{dx}\int_{x}^{7}\cos(\sin(t))\,dt = - \frac{d}{dx}\int_{7}^{x}\cos(\sin(t))\,dt = -\cos(\sin(x))\)

Recall the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus in its general form:

\(\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx}\int_{g(x)}^{h(x)} f(t) \ dt = h'(x)f(h(x))-g'(x)f(g(x))\)

Then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle I_{a} &= \frac{d}{dx}\int_{x}^{7}\cos(\sin(t))\,dt \\ &= \left(\frac{d}{dx}7\right)\cos(\sin(7)) - \left(\frac{d}{dx}x\right)\cos(\sin(x)) \\ &= -\cos(\sin(x))\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We have via the fundamental theorem of calculus that

$\displaystyle I_{a} = \frac{d}{dx}\int_{x}^{7}\cos(\sin(t))\,dt = - \frac{d}{dx}\int_{7}^{x}\cos(\sin(t))\,dt = -\cos(\sin(x))$

Recall the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus in its general form:

$\displaystyle \frac{d}{dx}\int_{g(x)}^{h(x)} f(t) \ dt = h'(x)f(h(x))-g'(x)f(g(x))$

Then

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle I_{a} &= \frac{d}{dx}\int_{x}^{7}\cos(\sin(t))\,dt \\
&= \left(\frac{d}{dx}7\right)\cos(\sin(7)) - \left(\frac{d}{dx}x\right)\cos(\sin(x)) \\
&= -\cos(\sin(x))
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
We have via the fundamental theorem of calculus that

<math> \displaystyle I_{a} = \frac{d}{dx}\int_{x}^{7}\cos(\sin(t))\,dt = - \frac{d}{dx}\int_{7}^{x}\cos(\sin(t))\,dt = -\cos(\sin(x))</math>
Recall the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus in its general form:

<math> \displaystyle \frac{d}{dx}\int_{g(x)}^{h(x)} f(t) \ dt = h'(x)f(h(x))-g'(x)f(g(x)) </math>

Then

<math> \begin{align}
\displaystyle I_{a} &= \frac{d}{dx}\int_{x}^{7}\cos(\sin(t))\,dt \\
&= \left(\frac{d}{dx}7\right)\cos(\sin(7)) - \left(\frac{d}{dx}x\right)\cos(\sin(x)) \\
&= -\cos(\sin(x))
\end{align} </math>
statement_html:
Fundamental Theorem of Calculus

Evaluate and simplify \(\displaystyle I_{a} = \frac{d}{dx}\int_{x}^{7}\cos(\sin(t))\,dt\)
statement_raw:
'''Fundamental Theorem of Calculus'''

Evaluate and simplify <math> \displaystyle I_{a} = \frac{d}{dx}\int_{x}^{7}\cos(\sin(t))\,dt</math>
